    <item>
      <title>
	Apple sinks to 2-year low making Google largest company
      </title>
      <link>
	http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sciencetech/article-3587484/Apple-falls-90-2-year-low-Google-largest-co.html?ITO=1490&ns_mchannel=rss&ns_campaign=1490
      </link>
      <description>
	Shares of Apple sank below $90 for the first time in nearly two years amid fears the company is running out of ideas that can rival the success of its iPod and iPhone devices.
      </description>
      <enclosure url="http://i.dailymail.co.uk/i/pix/2016/05/12/article-doc-aj7t4-2gqALY4vPZ08bdc60e863f09b543-679_154x115.jpg" type="image/jpeg" length="4673"/>

      </guid>
      <media:description>Apple stock has slid sharply since mid-April, hit in part by the company's disappointing fiscal second quarter earnings, which showed a decline in revenues and the first quarterly drop ever in iPhone unit sales since 2007 ©Justin Sullivan (Getty/AFP/File)</media:description>

	Solar plane on global trip completes Arizona-to-Oklahoma leg
      </title>

      </link>
      <description>
	The solar powered aircraft flew 975 miles from Phoenix in Arizona to Tulsa in Oklahoma with Swiss adventurer Bertrand Piccard at the controls, completing the 11th leg of its 21,700 mile journey.
      </description>
      <enclosure url="http://i.dailymail.co.uk/i/pix/2016/05/13/article-urn:publicid:ap.org:3bdf9f77ab9a4f0783722e359bc420ff-2gqALY4vPZ08bdc60e863f14cd04-886_154x115.jpg" type="image/jpeg" length="27990"/>

      </guid>
      <media:description>In this photo provided by Solar Impulse, Bertrand Piccard acknowledges the crowd prior to the takeoff of "Solar Impulse 2," in Goodyear, Ariz., Thursday, May 12, 2016. The solar-powered airplane that landed in Arizona last week is headed to Oklahoma on the latest leg of its around-the-world journey.     <item>
      <title>
	Researchers say 16,000 year old lines in Bavarian cave were NOT made by humans
      </title>
      <link>
	http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sciencetech/article-3587646/Researchers-say-strange-16-000-year-old-lines-Bavarian-cave-thought-phallus-NOT-humans.html?ITO=1490&ns_mchannel=rss&ns_campaign=1490
      </link>
      <description>
	The find at the 75m long Mäanderhöhle cave in Bavaria was hailed as a major breakthrough, with hundreds of lines found to form patterns believed to be fertility symbols.
      </description>
      <enclosure url="http://i.dailymail.co.uk/i/pix/2016/05/12/20/3416DAC200000578-0-image-m-7_1463082333673.jpg" type="image/jpeg" length="7565"/>
      <pubDate>Fri, 13 May 2016 03:30:36 +0100</pubDate>
      <guid>
	http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sciencetech/article-3587646/Researchers-say-strange-16-000-year-old-lines-Bavarian-cave-thought-phallus-NOT-humans.html?ITO=1490&ns_mchannel=rss&ns_campaign=1490
      </guid>
      <media:description>Image from a 3D scan of the cave clouds and lines in the Mäanderhöhle cave.

The Mäanderhöhle cave near Bamberg was previously regarded as an archaeological sensation. It was thought to contain some of the oldest cave art in Germany. However, Julia Blumenröther, a former student at FAU?s Institute of Prehistory and Early History, has demonstrated in her Master?s thesis that the markings discovered inside the cave in 2005 are not fertility symbols carved by humans as previously thought. In fact, these lines occurred as a result of natural processes, the archaeologist says.
One of the caverns in the 75-metre long cave is full of spherical deposits of minerals known as cave clouds that form on rocks in a similar way to stalactites and stalagmites. In 2005, cave researchers discovered a large number of lines that looked like they could have been made by humans on the rock-hard surface of these cave clouds. An archaeologist studied these lines several years later and published his interpre</media:description>
      <media:thumbnail url="http://i.dailymail.co.uk/i/pix/2016/05/12/20/3416DAC200000578-0-image-m-7_1463082333673.jpg" width="154" height="115"/>
      <media:credit scheme="urn:ebu">Andreas Pastoors</media:credit>
      <media:content type="image/jpeg" url="http://i.dailymail.co.uk/i/pix/2016/05/12/20/3416DAC200000578-0-image-m-7_1463082333673.jpg"/>
    </item>

      <title>
	Florida schoolboy develops solid 'shampoo balls'
      </title>
      <link>
	http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sciencetech/article-3586828/Just-add-water-Schoolboy-develops-solid-shampoo-balls-away-plastic-bottles-won-t-leak-luggage.html?ITO=1490&ns_mchannel=rss&ns_campaign=1490
      </link>
      <description>
	The inventor behind Nohbo solid shampoo balls (pictured), Benjamin Stern, 16, from Florida, claims they are ideal for travelling, enabling travellers to pack what they need without leaks.
      </description>
      <enclosure url="http://i.dailymail.co.uk/i/pix/2016/05/12/13/3413690C00000578-0-image-m-47_1463056675130.jpg" type="image/jpeg" length="4821"/>
      <pubDate>Thu, 12 May 2016 18:12:04 +0100</pubDate>
      <guid>
	http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sciencetech/article-3586828/Just-add-water-Schoolboy-develops-solid-shampoo-balls-away-plastic-bottles-won-t-leak-luggage.html?ITO=1490&ns_mchannel=rss&ns_campaign=1490
      </guid>
      <media:description>A 16-year-old entrepreneur has invented the world's first solid 'shampoo balls' - eliminating the need for plastic bottles.
Each single-use ball contains the amount of shampoo for one hair-wash, and remains solid until mixed with water.
Nohbo shampoo is therefore perfect for travelling - allowing you to pack only what you need without leaks, spills or clunky plastic packaging. 
Currently available in 'Japanese Cherry Blossom', 'Smoky Sandalwood', and 'unscented', both the shampoo and the packaging it arrives in are entirely biodegradable, made from plant-based materials. 
© Solent News & Photo Agency
UK +44 (0) 2380 458800</media:description>

    <item>
      <title>
	'World's oldest hafted axe' may not have had a handle after all
      </title>
      <link>
	http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sciencetech/article-3586662/World-s-oldest-hafted-axe-not-handle-Archaeologists-admit-no-evidence-claim-believe-likelihood-high.html?ITO=1490&ns_mchannel=rss&ns_campaign=1490
      </link>
      <description>
	A statement issued by the Australian National University said 'the world's oldest hafted axe' – one with a handle – had been found in Western Australia. But these claims have now been called into question.
      </description>
      <enclosure url="http://i.dailymail.co.uk/i/pix/2016/05/10/16/3402374100000578-0-image-m-42_1462894324554.jpg" type="image/jpeg" length="8003"/>
      <pubDate>Thu, 12 May 2016 12:20:05 +0100</pubDate>
      <guid>
	http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sciencetech/article-3586662/World-s-oldest-hafted-axe-not-handle-Archaeologists-admit-no-evidence-claim-believe-likelihood-high.html?ITO=1490&ns_mchannel=rss&ns_campaign=1490
      </guid>
      <media:description>EMBARGOED 10-MAY-2016 20:00 GMT.
Axe flakes from the dig.  The world's oldest axe has been dug up in Australia, showing early Aborigines were much more technically advanced than previously thought.  The axe dates back between 46,000 and 49,000 years, which coincides with the aborigines first arrival on the continent.  The hafted axe - which has a handle attached - could be 15,000 years older that the earliest found in Japan while in most countries such developments only took place 10,000 years ago.  Professor Sue O'Connor, lead archaeologist from the Australian National University, said: "This is the earliest evidence of hafted axes in the world. Nowhere else in the world do you get axes at this date.î</media:description>

      </title>

      </link>
      <description>
	Utah firm Nikola has revealed the  'Nikola One', which is capable of pulling 80,000 pounds and boasts six motors, and a hi-tech touchscreen cockpit.
      </description>
      <enclosure url="http://i.dailymail.co.uk/i/pix/2016/05/11/19/340D770700000578-0-image-m-15_1462991116755.jpg" type="image/jpeg" length="8555"/>
      <pubDate>Thu, 12 May 2016 08:57:13 +0100</pubDate>
      <guid>
	http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sciencetech/article-3585448/The-Tesla-truck-world-Hybrid-electric-natural-gas-cab-pull-80-000-pounds-1-200-miles-stops.html?ITO=1490&ns_mchannel=rss&ns_campaign=1490
      </guid>
      <media:description>Tesla is getting into trucking. At least his first name is.

The Nikola Motor Company, a Utah-based startup, has unveiled a compressed natural gas-electric hybrid semi aimed at disrupting the long-haul trucking industry the way the Tesla Model S did the car business.
The company is run by Trevor Milton, a former executive at dHybrid Systems, which developed a CNG system for tractor-trailers that?s now owned by Worthington Industries. Along with Faraday Future, Nikola is the latest automotive outfit named after an electrical pioneer to seemingly appear from the ether.
The truck, called the Nikola One, has been developed in secret for the past three years. It features a 150-gallon dHybrid storage system stacked behind its cab that fuels a turbine generator, which charges a 320-kilowatt-hour battery pack that drives six motors, one for each wheel. In this way, it works much like a diesel-electric locomotive.
It?s not a conversion vehicle. The truck?s chassis was engineered specifically f</media:description>

      <media:content type="image/jpeg" url="http://i.dailymail.co.uk/i/pix/2016/05/11/19/340D770700000578-0-image-m-15_1462991116755.jpg"/>

      </link>
      <description>
	A SpaceX capsule is headed back to Earth with precious science samples from NASA's one-year space station resident.
      </description>
      <enclosure url="http://i.dailymail.co.uk/i/pix/2016/05/11/22/340E69CC00000578-0-image-m-47_1463003706870.jpg" type="image/jpeg" length="4333"/>

      <guid>
	http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sciencetech/article-3584897/SpaceX-Dragon-departs-space-station-heads-home-cargo.html?ITO=1490&ns_mchannel=rss&ns_campaign=1490
      </guid>
      <media:description>In this photo released by SpaceX, a SpaceX capsule containing science samples from NASA's one-year space station resident, approaches the Pacific Ocean, a few hundred miles off the Southern California coast, Wednesday, May 11, 2016. Nearly 4,000 pounds of items fill the Dragon, including blood and urine samples from astronaut Scott Kelly's one-year mission. Kelly returned to Earth in March and has since retired from NASA. Researchers will use the medical specimens to study how the body withstands long journeys in space, in preparation for an eventual mission to Mars in the 2030s.  (SpaceX via AP)</media:description>

    <item>
      <title>
	World's oldest hafted axe unearthed in Australia used by early Aborigines
      </title>
      <link>
	http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sciencetech/article-3583154/World-s-oldest-hafted-axe-unearthed-Australia-49-000-year-old-tool-shows-early-Aborigines-one-history-s-advanced-civilisations.html?ITO=1490&ns_mchannel=rss&ns_campaign=1490
      </link>
      <description>
	Researchers from the Australian National University have said the axe (pictured) dates to between 46,000 and 49,000 years ago, shortly after people first arrived in Australia.
      </description>
      <enclosure url="http://i.dailymail.co.uk/i/pix/2016/05/10/16/3402374100000578-0-image-m-42_1462894324554.jpg" type="image/jpeg" length="8003"/>
      <pubDate>Wed, 11 May 2016 08:53:03 +0100</pubDate>
      <guid>
	http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sciencetech/article-3583154/World-s-oldest-hafted-axe-unearthed-Australia-49-000-year-old-tool-shows-early-Aborigines-one-history-s-advanced-civilisations.html?ITO=1490&ns_mchannel=rss&ns_campaign=1490
      </guid>
      <media:description>EMBARGOED 10-MAY-2016 20:00 GMT.
Axe flakes from the dig.  The world's oldest axe has been dug up in Australia, showing early Aborigines were much more technically advanced than previously thought.  The axe dates back between 46,000 and 49,000 years, which coincides with the aborigines first arrival on the continent.  The hafted axe - which has a handle attached - could be 15,000 years older that the earliest found in Japan while in most countries such developments only took place 10,000 years ago.  Professor Sue O'Connor, lead archaeologist from the Australian National University, said: "This is the earliest evidence of hafted axes in the world. Nowhere else in the world do you get axes at this date.î</media:description>
      <media:thumbnail url="http://i.dailymail.co.uk/i/pix/2016/05/10/16/3402374100000578-0-image-m-42_1462894324554.jpg" width="154" height="115"/>
      <media:credit scheme="urn:ebu">Stuart Hay / SWNS.com</media:credit>
      <media:content type="image/jpeg" url="http://i.dailymail.co.uk/i/pix/2016/05/10/16/3402374100000578-0-image-m-42_1462894324554.jpg"/>
    </item>

    <item>
      <title>
	Winter death rate for America's bees jumps from 22% to 28%
      </title>
      <link>
	http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sciencetech/article-3583266/This-stings-Winter-death-rate-Americas-honeybees-jumps.html?ITO=1490&ns_mchannel=rss&ns_campaign=1490
      </link>
      <description>
	After two years of improvement, America's honeybees had another tough and deadly winter, probably because of mites, according to a new federal survey.
      </description>
      <enclosure url="http://i.dailymail.co.uk/i/pix/2016/05/10/article-urn:publicid:ap.org:f3f8ba0d92f44818b2f6ca254929c721-3A2Dy098f29967bdbd3699c7570d-921_154x115.jpg" type="image/jpeg" length="39758"/>
      <pubDate>Tue, 10 May 2016 19:34:46 +0100</pubDate>
      <guid>
	http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sciencetech/article-3583266/This-stings-Winter-death-rate-Americas-honeybees-jumps.html?ITO=1490&ns_mchannel=rss&ns_campaign=1490
      </guid>
      <media:description>FILE - In this April 20, 2015 file photo, honeybees gather at the entrance to their new hive on the lawn of the Governor's mansion, at the Capitol In Olympia, Wash. After a couple years when American honey bee deaths in winter decreased, colony loss went back up last winter, probably because of tiny mites, according to a new federal survey released Tuesday, May 10, 2016. And year-to-year losses were even worse. The annual survey of beekeepers showed the winter colony loss rate was 28 percent, up from 22 percent. That¿s about average over the past decade but higher than the 17 percent that beekeepers call acceptable. But it is still lower than peak winter loss rates of 36 and 32 percent nine and ten years ago.  (AP Photo/Ted S. Warren, File)</media:description>
      <media:thumbnail url="http://i.dailymail.co.uk/i/pix/2016/05/10/article-urn:publicid:ap.org:f3f8ba0d92f44818b2f6ca254929c721-3A2Dy098f29967bdbd3699c7570d-921_154x115.jpg" width="154" height="115"/>
      <media:credit scheme="urn:ebu">Associated Press Photo</media:credit>
      <media:content type="image/jpeg" url="http://i.dailymail.co.uk/i/pix/2016/05/10/article-urn:publicid:ap.org:f3f8ba0d92f44818b2f6ca254929c721-3A2Dy098f29967bdbd3699c7570d-921_154x115.jpg"/>
